{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3678319,"name":"Emil","username":"GronkBaby","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/g/ba8739/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-07-10T18:01:30.017Z","cooked":"

Hi everyone!
Let me preface this by saying I’m pretty new to PCB-design. My current PCB-schematic looks like this (I don’t have the pcb design yet bcs I haven’t decided the design rule for the CAN traces):

Screenshot 2025-07-10 at 20.54.491042×1010 66.6 KB

Just a bit of an explanation:
CN1 is a wago connector which should give power to a cancoder
CN2-4 are wago connectors for the CAN wires of both steer, drive motors and cancoder (I’m going to cut off one pair of the CAN wires of each device, since I only need one pair)
I’m running everything over a twisted cable ethernet, so that’s why you see the ethernet jacks

Okay, now for the issue. Basically, from what I know, I need to target a differential impedance of 120 ohms on the PCB. My plan was to use a 4-layer pcb, with the top layer for CAN, next layer a ground-plane (bcs I’ve been told that’s good, I’m not really sure), then power on the next layer, and leave one copper layer blank.

I found this Altium calculator and it’s asking me for dielectric thickness: Differential Microstrip Impedance Calculator

I found some sort of dielectric thickness from the PCB manufacturer JLCPCB, here but I don’t know if its the right one:

Screenshot 2025-07-10 at 21.03.351478×542 59.5 KB

I guess I’m struggling to understand what exactly dielectric thickness means. Is it from the bottom of the copper to the ground plane that’s right underneath (so 0.2104 mm in this case)? Does it matter that the ground plane isn’t “connected” to the copper trace? Isn’t the ground-plane a dielectric also, so why wouldn’t we factor that into the dielectric thickness?

I’m pretty confused so I would appreciate any help

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-07-10T20:50:45.270Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":19,"reads":213,"readers_count":212,"score":182.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":504133,"topic_slug":"pcb-for-swerve-module-struggling-to-understand-a-bit-of-everything","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":4,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://resources.altium.com/p/differential-microstrip-impedance-calculator","internal":false,"reflection":false,"title":"Differential Microstrip Impedance Calculator","clicks":2}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pcb-for-swerve-module-struggling-to-understand-a-bit-of-everything/504133/1","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3678379,"name":"Jim Sokoloff","username":"sokoloff","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sokoloff/{size}/231724_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-10T19:32:13.188Z","cooked":"

On the RJ45, 3-4 is not a twisted pair on Ethernet cable. 1-2, 3-6, 4-5, and 7-8 are, so use one of those for CAN. (Edit: my bad: you’re splitting a pair for DC power. That isn’t as bad. If you don’t have any use for the extra wires, you might as well run GND on 4&5 and 12V on 3&6.)

For a small PCB, I wouldn’t bother with the 120ohm characteristic impedance. I made some 2-layer connector boards and didn’t give the first thought to impedance and they worked fine. (“Worked for me” isn’t a great argument by itself, but CAN is pretty forgiving at 1Mbps.)

I’d also think really hard before using the same connector for two different things on a single board. I used 5-pin JST-XH to carry 12V, GND, 5V, CAN-H, and CAN-L. If I needed just CAN, I could populate just two pins. Likewise if I needed just one power voltage. (Our buck converters were fine with the common grounding of the 12 and 5 volt systems.

I also put PTCs to protect the power rails from shorts. One per connector, so a fault on one connected load would only take that load out and not the entire rail.

To answer your direct question, it’s the total distance between the copper layers. (Don’t count the copper layers being used, just the space that’s taken up by intervening FR4 or non-participating copper layers.)

Don’t forget that capacitance to ground plane(s) will alter the impedance of the system.

I have not tried to do striplines before; sorry! I’d start by checking the standard thickness of the FR4 material between layers, your copper thickness, and use a calculator to pick your trace width and spacing after you decide if its ground plane on top, bottom, or neither.

Another thing. What exactly is the point of the ground plane in this instance? I’m not connecting it to the CAN H or CAN L lines, I’m just replacing the ground trace for the power of the CANcoder with a ground plane. How does that reduce interference?

Sorry if this is a stupid question

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-07-10T20:48:19.297Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":89,"readers_count":88,"score":17.8,"yours":false,"topic_id":504133,"topic_slug":"pcb-for-swerve-module-struggling-to-understand-a-bit-of-everything","display_username":"Emil","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":64351,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/pcb-for-swerve-module-struggling-to-understand-a-bit-of-everything/504133/7","reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3678429,"name":"Rod","username":"Weldingrod1","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/weldingrod1/{size}/162109_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-10T20:50:33.507Z","cooked":"

Shielding and control of impedance. Without the ground plane in the PCB a close aluminum part will change your impedance. YMMV on what “close” is Its been a lotta-lotta years since I looked at stripline calculations! And I’m a mech-E anyway…

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":10,"updated_at":"2025-07-10T20:50:33.507Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":36.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":504133,"topic_slug":"pcb-for-swerve-module-struggling-to-understand-a-bit-of-everything","display_username":"Rod","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":46443,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/pcb-for-swerve-module-struggling-to-understand-a-bit-of-everything/504133/8","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3678504,"name":"Paul Rensing","username":"prensing","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/prensing/{size}/65820_2.png","created_at":"2025-07-10T22:38:50.785Z","cooked":"

Just in case people don’t know, this is essentially the same as the Swyft CAN-nect system. SWYFT CANnect Wiring System – SWYFT Robotics

No harm in doing your own though.
